reviewText: What else can you say about three guys that have been making music together for almost 40 years.  I purchased this DVD after seeing the live show in Johnson City, TN.  The two were very similar.  These guys still rock as hard as ever, and it's amazing how much stage presence they have.  If you've never had the chance to see That Lil' Ol' Band From Texas live, this is the next best thing.

reviewText: I'm from Texas.  I like ZZ Top!  :-DI like this DVD.  But, I agree with too many camera changes. It would be cool if they could go back and remaster this with only 2 or 3 of the 42 million cameras they used!  ;-)  That way we might see 10 second shots of some fine lead, bass, and drums.

reviewText: ZZ Top has long been known as an outstanding live act, one of the best in the business. Loud, proud, three guys, three chords, with so much cool it just drips from the stage. Having seen these guyzz live twice, I know they can bring the funk better than most. Problem is, how does this brilliant of a live band not release anything live (except for side one of Fandango and the second half of XXX, and the bonus tracks on the Tres Hombres and Fandango remasters) until now? Well, regardless of the situation, that's been remedied. I picked this up at Wal-Mart for 10 bucks, and it is ABSOLUTELY worth every penny and then some. The band is hitting on all cylinders. Billy is playing like a madman, Dusty's holding the groove, and Frank is killer on the skins. Sure, Billy lip syncs during Legs. Sure, they use synthesizer backing tracks on some songs. It doesn't matter. What does matter is that this band just brings it, every night, every song. The show is filmed very well, very clear and sharp. The sound is amazing and the set list is so full of hits even a classic rock station can't keep up. The Eliminator hits? Check. La Grange/Tush? Check. Bus Jesus? Check. Cheap Sunglasses? Check. Plus, the bonus features are very cool too. There is a poker game where the band discusses their past and tells all sorts of stories. They show all the pre-show goings-on that happen before the band hits the stage. There is a cool photo-shoot. And they also have a tremendous cover of Hendrix's Foxey Lady, which they take and make it heavy ZZ-style. Overall, this is one of the best concert dvds I own, right there with Clapton's Crossroads Festivals, SRV's Live At The El Mocambo, Joe Bonamassa's Live At Rockpalast, and Led Zeppelin's DVD anthology. They have waited a very long time to do this, but when they did, they did it right. Get it, turn it loud, put on your cheap sunglasses, and like ZZ say: bear down on the meat, ease up on the potato salad.
summary: ZZ Top's first live release lives up to their reputation

reviewText: How could one not give 5 stars to one of the greatest influential bands of all time?  I could listen to Billy Gibbons play guitar all day and the man can maintain a grip on his audience throughout any performance. If there was one bummer about this show, it would have to be how bland the stage setup is.  That comes from seeing them in concert on a very blowed out stage for their Recycler tour.  The whole stage was made to look like a salvage yard with crushed cars piled high, old chain link fence and barb wire.  This didn't detract from the performance however.  And the frequent changing of the angles of the concert didn't bother me at all.  And you'll just love the sound if you have 5.1 digital or surround sound.  A great concert from a great band and a must for any music video collection. I love it.
summary: A great show from a great band

reviewText: SIMPLY OUTSTANDING!!!! This is ZZ Top's first live Dvd. It was filmed at Nokia Theater, before a packed crowd, in Dallas, Texas. I'm not sure of the date of the filming, but it is very recent. This performance shows a well mature, well polished, ZZ Top, who are Rock veterans. This Dvd proves they are seasoned veterans. The concert is outstanding. The presentation, the dvd liner notes, the package, and the product are great. The concert song set consists of 17 of their classic songs. Some highlights include the performances of "Cheap Sunglasses", "Legs", and "LaGrange". Also, there is some good humor included, like on the introduction of "Pearl Necklace",and "Blue Jean Blues". The dvd contains excellent bonus features, which include "the Dallas show day", a discussion of all 3 members on the history and story of the band, and a bonus on stage performance of Jimi Hendrix's "Foxey Lady". The dvd ends with Billy Gibbons discussing what he likes about Texas. This is a very entertaining dvd that well fits the 5 star criteria. It is definitly worth buying, watching and enjoying.
summary: ZZ Top - Live from Texas = "Outstanding Concert"!!!!! - A "Must-Have" For Any ZZ Top Fan Period !!!!!

reviewText: Lets face it these guys ain't getting any younger, and there vocals are starting to show it. I know there singing isn't what it was some 15 or so years ago and it shows on this dvd. I have a pretty nice system that really shows any flaws such as if one dvd has better sound on it than another. Theres also slightly to much echo effect that doesn't help the sound quality either. reviewText: These guys are pretty darn good and man does live in texas really bring it out.  Great concert with good camera work, sound and of course available in blu-ray picture quality.  The little ol band from Texas is not very little anymore nor old, just classic.  There guitar work is incredible and can take a chair up against any other rock band of this era as being the best of the best.  I am not saying there the greatest rock band of all time but at a table of the greatest, a chair is for sure reserved for them, in my opinion.  My only issue is that Dusty Hill would do more singing.  He has a good voice and would be nice to see him contribute more in that area.Peter J. Miller

reviewText: Anyone who is a fan of ZZ Top (and who isn't) needs to check this dvd out, this concert captures the band doing what they do best, play live to their adoring fans, the song list includes the standards (Sharp Dressed Man, Legs, La Grange, Tush,) as well as older songs like Cheap Sunglasses, Jesus just left Chicago, and the infamous "Pearl Necklace" as well as some blues "Blue Jean Blues and Rough Boy" the concert showcases the bands three members Frank Beard on drums, Dusty Hill on bass and Billy Gibbons on guitar, there is excellent camera work on the band as well as the audience, if you haven't had the thrill of seeing the band live this is the next best thingRazorback fan

reviewText: Eliminator is very possibly the best album ZZ Top has recorded.  In a brilliant move, the little old band from Texas, retooled their down and dirty, blues and boogie image, as part of the marketing strategy for Eliminator, successfully transforming themselves into cool, hip, sophisticated, modern rock icons.  The makeover proved to be a turning point in the band's career.  Bolstered by the popularity of their music videos, the band rocketed to new heights of popularity.  ZZ Top never looked back, and although the trio has been together for decades, Live From Texas is their first full length concert DVD.A first class production in every way, guitarist Billy Gibbon, bass player Dusty Hill and drummer Frank Beard, are captured in a performance that sparkles and shines like a diamond.  These slicked up, sharp dressed men are consummate pros, who put on a tight, well choreographed show, churning like a well oiled machine through some of the best of their catalog.  Showmanship is a big part of ZZ Top, though minus acrobatics or any wasted motion.  With boots firmly on the ground, the slow rocking, rather laid back Hill and Gibbons, are fascinating and fun to watch, as on Waitin' For the Bus.  The lighting scheme is often a cool blue (like the DVD cover), which generally seems to fit well with the mood of the performance.  The band's sound is huge and full, seemingly more than just a three piece.  The stage setup is wide open and spacious, with a slick, simple modern look.  Symmetry was apparently a design criteria.  The back wall appears to be clean and plain, but is deceptively complex.The seventeen songs preformed, span the band's history.  With four selections from Eliminator, and just Pin Cushion and Rough Boy from the post Eliminator era, the emphasis is definitely on the early years.  The band executes the songs so effortlessly, and in such a smooth low key manner, that at times it might appear that they are performing on cruise control.  The truth might be that the Texans are just the coolest, and least pretentious of rock stars.  ZZ Top tunes are typically short and sweet.  The concert seems to flow along quickly, even though the band seems to prefer staying in a set groove, slowing down the tempo of some of the songs.  Billy treats us to some really down and dirty side work, on Just Got Paid.  Things get bluesy on Rough Boy and Blue Jean Blues, but the performance finishes strongly with Gimme All Your Lovin', Sharp Dressed Man, Legs, and a super twangy Tube Snake Boogie.  The guys really loosen up on an extended version of La Grange, then proceeding straight into Tush to end the show.The paper bound case is a space saver.  The liner notes are informative, but erroneously state that Pin Cushion is from Afterburner, when it is actually from the album Antenna.  The bonus features include a killer live performance of Hendrix's Foxey Lady.  `Dallas Show Day', is a short feature about the band and preparation for a show.  The guys reminisce while playing cards, in `Poker Game'.  And `Photo Shoot' spotlights ZZ Top mugging for the camera, on location in a western town.  Live From Texas is just what most fans want, a virtuoso live performance, with some cool behind the scenes goodies.  If you like the band, you won't be disappointed by this DVD.  Enjoy, and have mercy.
Title: N/A
